topic.title: Feature Breakdown
topic.p: Mingle allows you to break down features in a way that makes sense to your team.
We recommend you answer the following questions before you begin breaking down features into Mingle cards.

col.p: Will setting up relationships between your card types help you break down your feature?

bullets.item: If so, consider using card trees.
A lighter weight method to create a relationship between your cards is the relationship property.
Sometimes, no relationship between your cards is needed and that's okay!

col.p: What type of work is required to complete the feature and do I want to track all of it together or separately?

row.col: Determining the types of work that is required to complete the feature will also help you figure out if a card tree makes sense.

col.p: Which card views will help your team be more effective? How will they want to filter these views?

row.col: Mingle allows you to quickly slice and dice your card views. Your team members may want to see cards in different ways. Your QA may be interested in all bugs that have been reported for a feature, your developers may want to see how much work is left for a feature (bugs and stories), etc. You will not be able to predict every view your team will eventually need but it's worth thinking about as you decide what relationships you want to put in place (card tree, relationship property or none at all).
What type of reporting do I want?

Similar to identifying which card views will help your team, think about what other team members (e.g. project management and stakeholders) will want to see in your reports. If you use a card tree you will be able to use aggregate properties for your reporting.

bullets.item: Keep your Mingle project simple. Introduce more complexity and structure as you need it.
